div.l: Thus eedith the Millers tale
heer bigynneth the ꝓprolog͗e of the Reve
Whan folk hadde lawhen / at this nyce cas
Of Absolon / ⁊and hende Nicholas
Dyvers folk dyủersly / they seyde
But for the more part / they lowh ⁊and pleyde
Ne at his tale / I saw no man hym greeve
But it were only / Osewold the reeve
Bi cause he was / of carpenteris craft
A litel Ire / in his herte is laft
He gan to gruche / ⁊and blamed it a lite
Sitheek qduod he / ful wel cowde I hym quyte
With bleryng of a prowd Milleris eye
Yif that me list / to speke of ribawdye
But I am old / me list nat pleye for age
Gras tyme is don / my fodir is forage
This white top / writeth myne owne yeres
Myn herte is Also mowled / as myn heris
But yit I fare / as doth an open ers
That ilke frute / is euyr lenger the wers
Til it be rotyn /
can we nat be rype
We hoppen alwey / whil the wolrld wolwolworld wol pipe
For in our wil / ther stiketh eủer a nail
We haue an hoor hed / ⁊and a a greene tail
As hath a leek / for thouh our myht be gon
Our wil / desireth foly / eủere in oon
For whan we may nat do / than wol we speke
Yit in our Aisshen / old fier is reke
Foure gleedis han we / which I shl shalshlshal devise
Avaıı̄untyng / lyeng / angir ⁊and couetise
This foure sperkelꝭes / longen vnto the elde
Oure elde bonys / mon̄ wel ben vnwelde
But wil shal nat failen / that is soth
For yit have I alwey / a coltes toth
And many a yere is it / passed henne
Syn that my tappe of lyf / bi ganne to renne
For sekirly whan / I was born anoon
Deth drouh the tappe / of lyf and leet it gon
And eủere sithe / hath so the tappe ronne
